reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA cute fighting game that carries the spirit of old SNK games on the Neo Geo Pocket Color. Pocket Rumble focuses on reducing the barrier to entry of the genre using a simple two button combo system, while retaining the mind games and exciting strategy people love fighting games for. It's a game in which even a novice could immediately see the metagame after just a bit of practice and explanation, despite how casual it initially appears. It is incomplete as of now, but it looks like it'll become a pretty stellar game once the full release comes out, hopefully sometime this year.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you played SNK vs Capcom: MotM on the Neo Geo Pocket Color, or really any of the fighters on that, you'll be right at home here.  It distills fighting game mechanics down to a two-button configuration, and makes for a really nice, tight experience that really is easy to pick up but deep enough to invest a lot of time in.  The animations are really nice and the characters are clearly inspired by SNK's pocket designs, and in my book that's a good thing.  The color pallets are intentionally limited, but again, if you played the NGPC fighting games, you know what you're getting into here.  It's all intentional and the developers are achieving exactly what they set out to create.  If you aren't a fan of the NGPC fighting games, I can't say for sure how you'll react to all of this, but for the price I still think it's worth a try.

Note: I miss using the clicky little joystick on the NGPC.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just wanna keep this short for people looking for something that's straight to the point with this game.

Do you like the Neo-Geo Pocket Fighting Games? Yes.
Do you like games with very good netcode? Yes.
Do you like fighting games that are not complex? Yes
Do you like early access games? Yes.

Then buy this game now. $10 is a McChicken combo at McDonalds. That's nothing.


Do you hate early access games with a barebones amount of content? Yes.
Do you dislike games that have controls that frustrate you and makes the game difficult for you to enjoy? Yes.
Do you like fighting games with traditional controls (QCF, HCF, 360 motions, etc)? Yes
Do you you think you'll abandon this Kickstarter fighting game like Skullgirls? Yes

Then do not buy this game (as of right now). Wait for the devs to develop this game more. They still have a lot of work to do.

Early Access Review

*Game is still a work in progress however, I stand by my opinion in this review*

This game is easily accesible to new players who put in the time to learn and understand the systems. While the tutorial mode is not yet completed, there is some in game text that helps to explain the systems.

At a more advanced level the game demonstrates many of the higher level concepts demonstrated in other games like Street Fighter but feels unique in this game.

Please give this game a try and also keep in mind the devs are ACTIVELY working on the game and improving it.

Easy to learn, fun to play, tons to master.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Such a great game! I'm basically using this to actually build some solid fighting game fundamentals. In a more typical fighting game, I usually learn a character's special moves, and then I just only ever do special moves. So I never actually build any knowledge about when to play defensive, practicing combos, using normals for damage and spacing/poking! Because anyone can do the special moves in Pocket Rumble, the difference between a good player and a bad player is really stark! I wanna get gud! :D

Also, love the aesthetics of the game, both visually and in its sound/music. The training mode with its ability to turn on/off hit/hurtboxes is great.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not a heavy traditional fighting game player, but I have played Skullgirls casually and played Melee, PM, and Sm4sh competitively at my local scene.
Keeping this in mind, I have picked up pocket rumble pretty well, (1270~ points at the time of writing, rank 48~)

It has solid balance between the two current characters and I hope that it will keep doing so with the release schedule being a new character every month until the roster is finished. Online play is VERY smooth, using GGPO delay where gameplay up to 150 ping is still playable (though not as great as 60 and lower)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA while back I stood out on faith of backing this game. I'm an avid fighting game player. Although my favorite genre is rpgs, fighting games have always given me the spriit for a competitive edge. Pocket Rumble definitely satiates this desire but why? First and foremost, Pocket Rumble is a retro style fighting game in the veign of old pocket handheld fighters meant to bridge the skill gap between the casual and competitive player. It does this by using simplistic controls. Only two buttons are used with regular normals, air normals, and special moves. At first, the controls felt a little strange because specials are done by holding down the corner directions and holding the button down as well. However, after figuring out the controls, the special moves were pretty easy to adjust to. Each character has four specials and a meter bar. However, Every character's meter is used in a different way. I'll use the first two playable characters as an example. Tenchi has traditional shoto" character commands (I.E. Ryu and Ken) he utilizes a fireball and  anti air maneuvers and once his meter is filled he can use a special "super" fireball. Naomi
recommended: is strictly rush down. She uses a lot of forward advancing special moves with options to mix up the opponent. Her meter is used to make better versions of her specials and she is able to charge it up in the veign of king of fighters or dbz games. Each character moving forward is meant to specialize in their own form of meter building and special implementation
hoursPlayed: so much so that the characters become shout outs to many other famous fighting game series. WIth this variety in the style of play
voteText: even though only 2 characters are available as of this review
helpfulPercent: there is going to be a lot of depth to the systems. Even now Its hard for me to stop playing this game online for any amount of time because I'm enjoying it so much. It feels responsive and brings fighting games back to the basics of spacing
votesTotal: and mind games. It is difficult for new fighters to break into the genre and make an impact so I hope that anyone reading this review can give it a chance. Right now it is low on content but once the final product hits we will really have something special on our hands. I recommend looking under the hood of early access to take a peak though. You'll probably like what you see."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent! Not much to say that others haven't said.

The game has great netcode and a simple jump/weak/heavy control scheme.
Easy to play, hard to master.
Special moves are done by holding down+forward or down+back and then holding A or B.
Only 2 characters, but they seem well balanced thus far. Naomi is a terror at close range that can murder you for panicking while Tenchi is a standard Ryu-esque go who thrives on spacing with fireballs and then hitting you with his plethora of anti-airs.

Kicking rad tunes, well polished animations. What else is there to say?

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI honestly don't know where to start with this game. I've been following its development as a backer for almost two years now, and to see it come to fruition is immensely satisfying, both as a competitive player, and a consumer. Yes, this game (currently in early access) only has two characters. Yes, the only two functions are ranked online play and training mode. And you know what? This game is already looking to be one of my favorite titles of 2016, alongside even Street Fighter V. The amount of attention and care put into this game by such a small development team is staggering, and it's provided one of the tighest, most thrilling competitive experiences I've had in recent years. I'm very eager to see this game grow and flourish as it deserves.

Early Access Review

Pocket Rumble is a lot of fun with a relatively shallow learning curve. It took a few minutes to get used to the special move mechanics, but once I did it was great to feel in control of a fighting game and not fighting with the controls for special moves.

The game looks great too. If you ever played the NGPC fighters you'll feel right at home.

Right now there's only two characters, but they both play well and feel complete. The game is fun, the netcode works well, and its very polished. So if you don't mind the limited content, this is a good early access purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm having a ton of fun with this!  The game is really easy to get into, and so far both the characters are really unique.  It's nice having a fighting game where it's easy to play multiple characters and actually be able to execute their moves without hours of practice.

I've played this game with people who are pretty new to fighting games, too, and it's an ideal game for that.  The controls take a little bit of getting used to for people who are already initiated into the traditional world of qcfs and srks, but they really sink in once you learn them.  No worrying about dropped DPs or complicated super inputs.

The music and animations are really adorable too (especially win animations).  Can't wait for more characters!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm something of a fighting game connoisseur, having been playing regularly since Street Fighter II hit the SNES. I'll be honest, the first time Pocket Rumble tried getting Kickstarted, I was somewhat skeptical and furious: this game claimed to be an homage to the SNK's classic scaled-down fighting games for the NeoGeo Pocket Color, but to me, it looked less like a tribute and more like full-on plagarism and art theft. Fortunately, Cardboard Robot Games apparently realized their mistake and their second attempt was altered significantly, offering up something that truly looked like it was inspired by those impressive for their time handheld fighters.

The game's mechanics are fairly simple: good for a beginner, but still fun for someone who's familiar with the genre. While most fighting games just give you a standard health bar, Pocket Rumble chooses to give each player a health meter with 10 segments. Each time a character takes a hit, they lose one segment and if a character loses all 10 segments, they lose the round. Health meters are replenished at the start of each round and interestingly enough, the losing player can choose to switch characters between rounds. You're limited to two attack buttons (light and heavy) and special moves are easy to perform - simply press either down-forward or down-back and an attack button, while super moves are similar, but require both buttons (as well as a full meter).

As of now, there are only two playable characters: Tenchi and Naomi. Tenchi plays something like a shoto-clone, while Naomi evokes a rushdown playstyle that reminds me of Terry Bogard. Cardboard Robot Games promises a new character each month, so hopefully they'll add some variety to the gameplay. There are also only three modes at the moment: local multiplayer, online multiplayer and training mode. There's also a brief overview of the gameplay mechanics, which will eventually be replaced with a full tutorial mode down the line.

TL;DR: It's still really early, but it shows a great deal of promise. I'll update this review once the game leaves early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've ever watched a fighting game and wanted to learn what was going on.

If you've ever wanted to learn how fighting games work and what all the fuss is about.

If you already play fighting games and have tried desperately for years to make your friends understand why you love them so much.

This is the game you need to play.

Fighting games always have a wall between the not-so-interesting How do I do this?" and the much more interesting "Why and when do I want to do this?" This game takes that wall and turns into a tiny ramp that you'll climb very quickly.

You'll be able to take part in that mental back and forth between you and your opponent
date: of figuring out what your opponent wants to do
hoursPlayed: how your opponent is going to beat what you want to do
voteText: what your opponent can't deal with and picking apart the weaknesses in each other's playstyle rather than wrestling with the game to figure out what you want to do. You'll be able to see and experience why any serious fighting game player can't help but let their passion and excitement leak out when they talk about their favourite games or moments.\n\nFor more technical stuff  I'm based in the UK and had a number of very playable matches against folks in the US
helpfulPercent:
the netcode is very stable. If you like to sink your teeth into the fine details of the game hitbox display and a frame data meter give you all the information you'll want are already in the game with full frame data in movelists coming later.
Training mode has all the essentials you need (most importantly a record function!).

Most importantly the game is absolutely adorable
votesHelpful: the character designs are amazing and the stages have extra effects that trigger whenever you hit the final round to really get your pulse racing. This is a game clearly made by people who love and understand fighting games and the people who play them.\n\nThe game despite being in early access is already a complete if small experience and I'm certainly convinced that it'll only get better as more characters
votesTotal: stages and game modes are added."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I excitedly backed this back in November of 2014, but as time passed my interest wained. Now that I've had a chance to play it in early access though, I can honestly say:

This is way better than I thought it would be!

The simplified controls make the game accessible, but at the same time I've had an absolute pleasure learning to play because the controls feel so fresh and original.  The animations are fluid, the effects looks great, and the scan lines somehow add a lot to how things look and feel.  The gameplay is fast paced and with GGPO, online play is flawless.

If you like fighting games at all, you should give this game a go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is still being developed (it's in beta), but what's there so far is of good quality and quite fun, yet accessible enough even if you can't do tricky joystick or button combinations.

The graphics may be simple, but you can tell the game was made by people who know what they're talking about when it comes to fighting games.

It runs on sweet, sweet GGPO, the benchmark for netcode for fighting games. (Basically, less laggy online matches.)

Not a fan of the skanlines? There's a slider to make them more or less visible, and you can them off completely.

The developers, Cardboard Robot Games, are actively listening feedback from players and active within and supportive of the community.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pocket Fighter is another failed attempt at luring begineers into fighting games.
The main flaw here is that you hold down a button to perform a special move.

Why is copying smash bros so hard?
The main issues are that you hold diagonal directions for special moves instead of up/down/left/right and you hold the special attack buttons instead of simply pressing them! So what you end up with is imput failure out the wazoo in a game about removing the barriers to fighting games.

Not since Rising Thunder has a fighting game" been so bad.
If you are a beginner to fighting games then you will enjoy this game but if you intermediate or above then this game will be a difficult ride and honestly Smash Bros is a better entry level game for beginners.

The studio may bring it around and I hope they do because we do need beginneer friendly fighting games but at present its not catering to the market it was designed for and its not catering to proffessionals.

Ascetics need a special mention because they are true to Neo Geo Pocket and its a nice blast to the past so good job there.

The game doesn't feel right and yes it is early days so that could change and hopefully it will.

Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needs
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The fights feel very dynamic.
The feeling can change from calm and controlled, to bursts of speed, to heavy impacts very quickly.

Combos are simple and easy to execute.
You can be somewhat creative, there are multiple solutions.

To do specials you have to hold the attack button, so that takes some getting used to.
But it's fine, and perfectly fits into the rythm of the game.

Online works great in fight.
There can be some waiting involved to find a player, but not such a big deal.

A friend and I played for 3 hours straight until our thumbs hurt.
And there's only 2 characters. :D

Looking forward to the release of the rest of the cast.

The character art is solid, heavily inspired by the NeoGeo Pocket games.
Honestly I would have suggested a more original pixel style.
But I can't hate on fandom too hard.
This is what they wanted to do, and they nailed it.

UI is on point.
Clear and creative.

The fact that it's developed using LÖVE is inspiring.
Been coding a game engine with the same framework.
It's nice to see someone else take that pony to town. ;)

Anyway, get the game.
It's a good time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI honestly thought this was better than Street Fighter. It had all of the look, and playability, and then went above and beyond with simplistic game style. When you're playing a game with someone new, you don't want the fact that you memorized the combos to make it impossible for them to beat you, you want a challenge. This game is all about art and timing over memorization. I would recommend it to anybody, even non-gamers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

a fun and accessible arcade fighter, with a pleasantly simplistic graphic style and simple button layout (only 2 buttons required). if you're looking to get into the fighting game scene and want to start out simple, this game is great for learning the basics.

i play using an SNES controller, and it works perfectly. the game immediately recognizes my controller, and it's just a matter of mapping the buttons i want to use.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI was playing Street Fighter 5 with Carlo and he knew nothing. I showed him Pocket Rumble and used the simple inputs and interface to teach him basic fighting game mechanics and fundementals such as spacing, zoning etc. His play was a lot better afterwards. I think this game strikes the perfect balance of being fun for new and experienced players. It is the perfect tool for getting into fighting games and learning tools that can be applied throughout the genre. Can't wait to see the finished product!
